Description: Mould-made amuletic figure in glazed composition, representing the ithyphallic Egyptian god Min; depicted as standing with raised right arm, leaning against back pillar, on small rectangular base; wearing long divine beard, double-plumed crown with possibly a sun disc; modelling simplified, with minimum of features shown; plain back pillar, pierced at head level for suspension; glazed surface intact with pale turquoise tinge; complete.
Curator's comments: The cult of the ithyphallic god Min is attested in Naukratis on the colossal statue of Horemheb, dated to the early Ptolemaic period. The inscription mentions that this Naukratite was a priest of Min (Yoyotte 1994-95, 671-673; Guermeur 2005, 135-137). Min appears however rarely in the material of Naukratis. See nonetheless the small bronze figure Boston, Museum of Fine Arts RES.86.71. Such amulets were "presumably worn by men in order to assimilate the god's virile powers" (Andrews 1994, 17). On amulets of Min: Andrews 1994, 17, fig. 11b; Herrmann et al. 2010, 53 (type 22). Andrews, C. 1994, Amulets of Ancient Egypt, London. Guermeur, I. 2005. Les cultes d’Amon hors-de-Thèbes, Turnhout. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart. Yoyotte, J. 1994/95, ‘Les contacts entre Égyptiens et Grecs (viie-iie siècles avant J.-C.) : Naucratis, ville égyptienne’, Annuaire du Collège de France, 669-82.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.173) (phase 3)
